an integer representing the origin of the middle alif:
  • 0: alif itself
  • 1: waw
  • 2: Yaa

classitems.description: List of Arabic personal pronouns

Normalization method for Arabic: it helps delete vocalization
* voc: delete vocalization
* alef: Replace all alef variants with the simple alef
* ihamza: Replace all beginning hamza variants with the simple alef
* yeh: Relace the alif maqsorah with yeh
* teh: Replace teh marbuta with heh
* _: Delete tatweel
classitems.name: normalize

params.name: opts

some options (optional) where each language defines its own
normalization options

classitems.description:
To recover the direction of writing for the given language
This can be done using the info.js instance of the target language. But, the direction is used a lot for presentation, so a centralized version is to be afforded, so we don't import the js file for each language in each webpage.

classitems.description:
The part of speech: Noun, Verb, Adjective,
Adverb, Preposition, Pronoun
classitems.name: PoS

classitems.description: The tense: Past, Present, Future
classitems.name: Tense

classitems.description: The aspect: Simple, Continuous, Perfect, PerfectContinuous
classitems.name: Aspect

classitems.description:
The mood: indicative, subjunctive, conditional,
optative, imperative, jussive, potential,
hypothetical, inferential
classitems.name: Mood

classitems.description:
The indicative can be considered the default mood.
A verb in indicative merely states that something happens,
has happened or will happen, without adding any attitude of the speaker.
The speaker uses imperative to order or ask the addressee to do the action of the verb.

The conditional mood is used to express actions that would have taken
place under some circumstances but they actually did not / do not happen.
Grammars of some languages may classify conditional as tense (rather than mood)
but e.g. in Czech it combines with two different tenses (past and present).

The action of the verb is possible but not certain.
This mood corresponds to the modal verbs can, might, be able to. Used e.g. in Finnish.

The subjunctive mood is used under certain circumstances in subordinate clauses,
typically for actions that are subjective or otherwise uncertain.
In German, it may be also used to convey the conditional meaning.
example: "Je veux que tu le fasses": I want that you to do it

classitems.description:
The jussive mood expresses the desire that the action happens;
it is thus close to both imperative and optative.
Unlike in desiderative, it is the speaker, not the subject who wishes that it happens.
Used e.g. in Arabic.
Means âin order toâ, occurs in Amazonian languages.
The quotative mood is used e.g. in Estonian to denote direct speech.

Expresses exclamations like âMay you have a long life!â or
âIf only I were rich!â In Turkish it also expresses suggestions.

The desiderative mood corresponds to the modal verb âwant toâ:
âHe wants to come.â Used e.g. in Turkish.

The necessitative mood expresses necessity and corresponds to the modal
verbs âmust, should, have toâ: âHe must come.â

Expresses surprise, irony or doubt. Occurs in Albanian,
other Balkan languages, and in Caddo (Native American from Oklahoma).
The voice: Active,Passive, Middle
classitems.name: Voice

classitems.description: The grammatical number: Singular, Dual, Plural
classitems.name: GNumber

classitems.description: The person: First, Second, Third.
classitems.name: Person

classitems.description: The gender: Masculine, Feminine, Neuter.
classitems.name: Gender

classitems.description:
This is a map to different morphology features:
  • POS
  • Tense
  • Aspect
  • Mood
  • Voice
  • Number: It returns Num
  • Case: It returns Case
  • Person: It returns Person
  • Gender: It returns Gender
We can access these features either by:
Morpho.Feature.feature_name
Or:
Morpho.Feature["feature_name"]
classitems.name: Feature
